Award.AwardTitle: Biogeographic and ecological diversification of trees across the Indonesian archipelago: developing indigenous leadership in biodiversity informatics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Indonesian archipelago contains forests with some of the highest local plant diversity on Earth, resulting from a complex geological and environmental history. Timber harvesting and oil palm expansion have drastically reduced the area of lowland forests, threatening this diversity before it has been discovered and understood. This project will pioneer new methods for recording tree species composition and environmental variables on five islands (Borneo, Sulawesi, New Guinea, Seram, Sumbawa), using local students and park rangers and utilizing extensive digital photography, as well as genetic data, all integrated into a "live" biodiversity informatics platform. From these data, the historical processes by which the forests were assembled will be discovered, and this will lead to a greater understanding of how forests will respond to future environmental changes.

Currently, most Indonesian biodiversity is managed by foreign institutions. In today's open source world, the megadiversity countries should lead the collection, digitization and networking of their own biodiversity information; this is the only realistic, sustainable solution to documenting biodiversity while it still exists. This project will develop capacity and leadership in biodiversity informatics in Indonesia, as well as in the US, via joint field expeditions, meetings, short courses and sustained interactions with local software developers. The informatics resources themselves will aid foresters and conservationists to better know and manage these forests.

This project is part of a 10-year effort to digitize and mobilize the scientific information associated with biological specimens held in U.S. research collections. The images and digitized data from this project will be integrated into the online national resource as outlined in the community strategic plan available at http://digbiocol.files.wordpress.com/2010/05/digistratplanfinaldraft.pdf.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Indonesian forests contain some of the highest biodiversity on earth, and represent one of the world's most exciting challenges for historical biogeography. Yet these forests are relatively understudied, and are also among those globally most highly threatened by landscape change. This project is contributing significantly to our understanding of the trees of this region. Teams of international and national scientists, parataxonomists, local forest rangers and villagers visited five islands across Indonesia (Borneo, Seram, Waigeo, Flores and Sulawesi) during a series of two-month expeditions. We inventoried forest sample plots (6 ha in total), and collected over 1,300 botanical specimens for taxonomic identification, DNA sequencing and ecological characterization. Several potentially new species were collected, which we are following up with taxonomic experts. Sequencing, phylogeny reconstruction and biogeographic analysis are still ongoing, but existing data, including over 25,000 high-definition plant images are already available at our project website (http://xmalesia.info). To augment the species number of one tree genus, Alangium, we also performed next generation DNA sequencing of herbarium specimens, during training of a female, Hispanic graduate student in the US. Our methodological success with Alangium points towards the widespread future use of herbarium specimens, from which DNA is usually difficult to extract, for phylogenetic analyses. Several training events in field and DNA methods were given in Indonesia during the project.

A second and parallel goal of this project was the online presentation of these biodiversity data in ways that permit their easy integration and re-use, and in the process to develop capacity in biodiversity informatics in Indonesia. We developed a comprehensive platform for our own data (see above), and associated analytical tools (biomatcher, SHIBA), and participated in the development of a Linked Open Data architecture for biodiversity (Darwin-SW). We involved local programmers extensively, and a biodiversity informatics conference and training course were offered as additional opportunities to engage local IT professionals and students. During our project, our Indonesian counterpart investigators were awarded a USAID PEER grant to extend our biodiversity platform and expedition methodology in order to perform botanical surveys of under-explored sites in West Kalimantan, harnessing the skills and enthusiasm of local amateur botanists as citizen scientists. We participated in this PEER project design, and in the pre-expedition training courses. The subsequent fieldwork was a great success, generating records and high-resolution images of over 1,000 species.  The inclusion of citizen scientists, and the use of DNA barcoding methods and high quality images are components of a new approach to taxonomic work that we have explored during this project, which we hope might contribute to more rapid documentation and discovery of plant taxa in these diverse but threatened ecosystems. Such issues were discussed during a project think tank held in Indonesia in 2015.

Overall, we were successful in meeting both fieldwork and informatics goals, and expect the analytical results to soon cast informative new light on the historical assembly of Indonesian forests. Throughout the years of this project, we have been generously supported and encouraged by our various Indonesian colleagues, and by the Indonesian government, and feel that this project represents a genuine international collaboration. The spin-off of our informatics activities into a number of independent, ongoing initiatives highlights this collaboration, and gives us hope for increased biodiversity exploration performed by Indonesian citizens living near to these magnificent forests.
